qas.question: What does it mean to say that God is omnipotent?
What is the feeling of God being everywhere?
What is the extent of God's knowledge?
What is infinite knowledge classified as?
What is the benevolence of God called?
What type of human is God portrayed as in some religions?
What is a God in monotheism?

answers.text: Supreme Being and principal object of faith

qas.question: How should monotheism not be portrayed?
What gender do theologians usually use to define human biological gender?
What has creating a non-corporeal being caused some religions to do regarding divine simplicity?

plausible_answers.text: as the Supreme Being and principal object of faith

qas.question: In biological gender, what is the universe conceived of?

plausible_answers.text: divine simplicity, and eternal and necessary existence

qas.question: What are some concepts of the universe according to theologians?

context: In monotheism and henotheism, God is conceived of <b11_0>as the <a7_0>Supreme Being and principal object of faith<b11_0/><a7_0/>. The concept of God as described by theologians commonly includes the attributes of <a3_0>omniscience<a3_0/> (<a2_0>infinite knowledge<a2_0/>), omnipotence (<a0_0>unlimited power<a0_0/>), <a1_0>omnipresence<a1_0/> (present everywhere), <a4_0>omnibenevolence<a4_0/> (perfect goodness), <b12_0>divine simplicity, and eternal and necessary existence<b12_0/>. God is also usually defined as a non-corporeal being <a5_0>without any human biological gender<a5_0/>, but the concept of God actively (as opposed to receptively) creating the universe has caused some religions to <b10_0>give "Him" the metaphorical name of "Father"<b10_0/>. Because God is conceived as not being a corporeal being, God cannot(some say should not) be portrayed <b8_0>in a literal visual image<b8_0/>; some religious groups use <a6_0><b9_0>a man (sometimes old and bearded)<b9_0/><a6_0/> to symbolize God because of His deed of creating man's mind in the image of His own.
